review.title: TrueLabel + Confusions: A Spectrum of Probabilistic Models in Analyzing Multiple Ratings
review.abstract: This paper revisits the problem of analyzing multiple ratings given by different judges. Different from previous work that focuses on distilling the true labels from noisy crowdsourcing ratings, we emphasize gaining diagnostic insights into our in-house well-trained judges. We generalize the well-known DawidSkene model (Dawid & Skene, 1979) to a spectrum of probabilistic models under the same "TrueLabel + Confusion" paradigm, and show that our proposed hierarchical Bayesian model, called HybridConfusion, consistently outperforms DawidSkene on both synthetic and real-world data sets.

metadata.title: TrueLabel + Confusions: A Spectrum of Probabilistic Models in Analyzing Multiple Ratings

sections.heading: 3. Experiments on Synthetic Data
sections.text: In this section, we use synthetic data to examine the accuracy of different models in restoring the fundamental truth, i.e., to estimate the true model parameters and designations. We synthesize the data using the DawidSkene model for three judges (J = 3) on a three-step metric (K = 3). For simplicity, we designate the three levels by "A," "B" and "C," the previous probabilities of which are assumed to be 0.05, 0.15 and 0.8, respectively. The three confusion matrices are shown in Figure 2. As you can see, the three matrices are not selected to favor any models, and in fact, the three matrices are not even suitable for rat hybrid confusion, because HybridConfusion never examines cells as 0. Through the experiments in this section, we examine the accuracy of restoring the basic truth for different models by varying the number of elements.

sections.heading: 4. Experiments on Real-World Data
sections.text: In this section, we report on the experimental results of a real world rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating-rating

sections.heading: 5. Related Work
sections.text: The need for a large amount of labelled data, inherent in many machine learning algorithms and applications, not only accelerates online crowdsourcing (e.g. from Amazon's MechanicTurk), readers interested in a detailed survey in this area are pointed out (Ipeirotis & Paritosh, 2011).While the low cost of crowdsourcing makes multiple labels feasible on numerous articles practically, it also requires principled approaches to distill real labels from the reviews of less than experts, among others (Sheng et al., 2008).Due to the importance of this issue, recent years have seen increasing interest in this issue, e.g., (Whitehill et al., 2009; Welinder et al., 2010; Perona et al., 2009).

sections.heading: 6. Conclusion
sections.text: In this paper, we generalize the DawidSkene model into a range of probable models under the "TrueLabel + Confusion" paradigm. Our proposed models, SingleConfusion and HybridConfusion, complement the well-known DawidSkene model to overcome its excessive drawbacks. We examine its advantages and disadvantages using both synthetic and real data, and demonstrate the benefits of HybridConfusion in different environments. In the future, we would optimize the assessment pipeline based on restored confusion matrices, such as targeted training and direction changes.

sections.heading: Acknowledgments
sections.text: We thank John Platt for the helpful discussion and the anonymous reviewer for the insightful and constructive comments.

Different from previous work that focuses on distilling the true labels from noisy crowdsourcing ratings, we emphasize gaining diagnostic insights into our in-house well-trained judges. We generalize the well-known DawidSkene model (Dawid & Skene, 1979) to a spectrum of probabilistic models under the same “TrueLabel + Confusion” paradigm, and show that our proposed hierarchical Bayesian model, called HybridConfusion, consistently outperforms DawidSkene on both synthetic and real-world data sets.
